and had a piti- ful, weary, and distracted air, though at the same time he was haughty and self-confident. 
Kutiizov was occupying a nobleman's castle of modest dimensions near Ostralitz. In the large drawing room which had become the commander in chief's office were gathered Ku- tiizov himself, Weyrother, and the members of the council of war. They were drinking tea, and only awaited Prince Bagrati6n to begin the council. At last Bagrati6n's orderly came with the news that the prince could no
